Countries have adopted "rules of war" (aka the Geneva Conventions) that severely limit the tactics military forces can use, or place requirements upon their use to limit civilian casualties and property damage.  Among these are the requirement that military forces wear distinctive uniforms, carry arms openly, operate under a chain of command, and wear distinctive insignia of rank.  Militaries are also required to use the minimum amount of force necessary to achieve tactical objectives, avoid collateral damage to civilians and property, treat prisoners humanely, etc. 

In "asymmetric" warfare, guerilla forces follow none of these rules.  This puts state-run military forces at a severe disadvantage.  Under the rules of many decades ago, an armed guerilla captured on the field of battle could be summarily shot.  Economic resources that support guerilla forces (farms, livestock, foodstocks) could be destroyed.  These tactics often (but not always) worked to win military victories over guerilla forces, but are now war crimes.

This presents a real dilemma for the US.  Our high-tech military has severe difficulty fighting an enemy that does not abide by the Geneva conventions, while world opinion demands that we do.  

My advice: don't get involved in asymmetric wars where our morality and laws put us at a great disadvantage.  Such wars are always wars of choice, not existential wars.  E.g., our decision to invade Afghanistan was a choice, not an imperative for national survival.
